element.name: Magnesium
element.availability: Magnesium is the eight most abundant element in the Earth's crust, about 2% by weight.
element.origin: From Magnesia ancient city in Asia Minor.
element.sources: Usually obtained by electrolysis of melted magnesium chloride found in sea water. China produces around 60% of the world's magnesium,
element.uses: Used in alloys to make airplanes, missiles, racing bikes and other things that need light metals. Also used in fireplace bricks, flashbulbs, pigments and filters.

notes.ptext: Magnesium metal and alloys are highly flammable in their pure form when molten, as a powder, or in ribbon form. Burning or molten magnesium metal reacts violently with water. Magnesium powder is an explosive hazard.

element.name: Manganese
element.sources: Most abundant ores are pyrolusite (MnO2), psilomelane [(BaH2O)2Mn5O10] and rhodochrosite (MnCO3). Manganese is mined in Burkina Faso and Gabon.
element.uses: Used in steel, batteries, axles, rail switches, safes, plows and ceramics.

element.name: Meitnerium
element.colour: unknown, but probably metallic and silvery white or grey in appearance
element.dwho: Physicists at the Heavy Ion Research Laboratory
element.origin: Named after Lise Meitner, a Swedish physicist who helped discover protactinium and first split the nucleus of uranium, creating what her team dubbed "fission".
element.sources: First synthetically produced by bombarding Bi209 with accelerated nuclei of Fe58.

notes.ptext: In August of 1997 the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry announced the official naming of this element as Meitnerium.
Element 109 was previously known as Unnilennium; from the latin for "one zero nine".

element.name: Mendelevium
element.colour: unknown, but probably metallic and silvery white or grey in appearance
element.dwho: G.T.Seaborg, S.G.Tompson, A. Ghiorso, K.Street Jr.
element.origin: After the scientist Dmitri Ivanovitch Mendeleyev, who devised the periodic table.
element.sources: Purely synthetic element. Made by bombarding einsteinium with helium ions.

element.name: Mercury
element.state: liquid at 298 K (the heaviest known elemental liquid)
element.origin: From the Greek god Mercury who was the messenger to the gods and was known for his speed; Hg from mercury's Latin name Hydrargyrum, which comes from the Greek word "hydrargyros" ("hydor" for water and "argyros" for silver).
element.sources: Mercury is rarely found in native form. Most mercury is found in the minerals; cinnabar (the main source), corderoite, livingstonite as well as some others. 50% of the world's mercury comes from Spain and Slovenia, with much of the rest coming from Russia and the USA.
element.uses: Used in thermometers, barometers, diffusion pumps, coulometers, fluorescent lamps, mercury switches, insectisides, and batteries. Gaseous mercury is used in mercury-vapour lamps.

notes.ptext: Causes neurological and kidney damage and blindness. Also associated with birth defects. Very damaging to aquatic life. It is found in paint, batteries, thermometers, electrical equipment, fluorescent lights and plastics. Also used in gold mining industry. Batteries account for 88% of the mercury content in municipal solid waste
Because of mercury's ability to rapidly corrode aluminium, transport by aircraft is restricted.

element.name: Molybdenum
element.sources: Found in the minerals molybdenite (MoS2) and wulfenite (MoO4Pb) and as a byproduct of copper mining.
element.uses: Used in steel, aircraft, missiles, filaments in electric heaters, lubricants and protective coatings in boiler plates.

notes.ptext: Molybdenum has been found to have a role in the biology of all classes of organisms. It is found in two groups of enzymes, the nitrogenases and the molybdopterins.
